characters: ON MICKEY LEE AND ROLAND LAMONT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining lightly in the harbor and the water around the moored boats looks dirty and cold. We PICK UP a sad excuse for a boat sitting in an end slip. It's a sea-gull-shitcovered, thirtyfoot cabin cruiser that hasn't cruised in a long, long time. A ratty looking unpainted plywood addition has been nailed to the top of the cabin. It's partially covered with a blue plastic tarp.

dialogues.speaker: FALL
dialogues.text: The tarp moves and SHANE FALCO's half-naked torso emerges from under it. Shane is late twenties, golden boy handsome, but quickly going to seed. He looks hung over. Shane glances up at the sky and rain. He pulls on the top part of an old patched wet suit and zips it up. He shivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're BUZZING around the harbor with Shane in an old Zodiac inflatable DINGHY. Shane has pulled up the attached rubber hood to his wet suit so that only the white, pasty oblong of his face is visible. It's still raining as he steers the little boat around the sailboats and yachts. He pulls up to a fiftyfoot sailboat and CUTS the ENGINE. With practiced moves, he ties the dinghy to the rear rail of the sailboat and clips a bill for services rendered on the sailboat's stern line. He slips on a weight belt,    puts on a pair of old gaffer taped goggles,    jams the end of a air-hose in his mouth, and    falls backward out of the dinghy and into the    water.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: It's dark, dirty and murky. Suddenly, Shane floats INTO FRAME and comes AT us with a long spatula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He attacks the underside of the sailboat which is covered with green algae muck that hangs a foot off the bottom of the boat. The spatula scrapes away the green mess revealing the pure white underside of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: As he scrapes. Muck from the boat floats past him. This doesn't look like fun. As he works, he happens to look down and notices something on the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amidst the beer cans and other trash, something golden is sitting on the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Shane takes a deep pull on his hose, lets it go and drifts down. A shaft of sunlight penetrates the murky water and reveals a broken trophy half-buried in the mud. Shane kneels over it and picks it up. The trophy is almost a full-size football rendered in bronze attached to a broken base. Shane turns "the ball" over in his hands. He grips the seams like he's done this before. Then he holds the football out in front of him. Suddenly, he starts barking garbled signals to an imaginary offense. He turns to his running back as he yells something like "Blue 31!" It comes out in bubbles He cocks his left leg and his wide receiver goes in motion. Then on the "snap" he turns and starts a five step drop. He moves in slow motion because hey... he's underwater! He executes a perfect play action fake on the third step of his drop, and looks "down field" for his receivers. But there's a blitz! He steps up in the pocket but a linebacker's arm almost takes his head off. He dodges, he bobs, he weaves in a kind of delicate ballet. He rolls left and keeps looking for the open man. Suddenly he points down field, pulls up and cocks his arm. The "ball" comes behind his ear and snaps forward in a perfect release. The trophy spins OUT OF FRAME but we HOLD ON Shane as he watches his pass. Suddenly, he throws both arms up in a touchdown signal. We STAY ON him as he freezes in this pose of victory, fifteen feet underwater, on the trash-covered, muddy bottom of Marina Del Rey.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Bam! A Miami Dolphin linebacker crushes a Washington Redskin running back and lands on his throat, elbow first. It's a beautiful fall day in November and Miami is beating the Skins in front of seventy-six thousand crazed Washington fans. The Redskins are at their home stadium better known as "The Big O."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN MADDEN and PAT SUMMERALL are calling the game in shirtsleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That play, my friends, sums up the Redskins' running game all day long. Now Washington calls their last time out. Madden leans over to do his diagram that shows up on your TV screen. We STAY ON him as he draws and explains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, the Dolphins do this as good as anybody. See, in a four, three, two, two, you got the guards... boom!... Plugging up the middle, then the corners... boom and boom!     Are free to box...    leaving the middle    linebacker to cut off    the trap here...    boom!

dialogues.speaker: SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: Third and twenty-two, but forget the first down with eight seconds showing and the Skins down by a touchdown.

dialogues.speaker: MADDEN
dialogues.text: Could be the last play.

dialogues.speaker: SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: Could be the last play of the season if the players go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redskin quarterback EDDIE MARTEL is conferring with Redskin head coach BUD TILDON near the bench. Madden and Summerall continue OVER.

dialogues.speaker: MADDEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Take it all in, people. This could be it for 2,000. We MOVE TO veteran Redskin center REESE EVANS, 38, standing on the sidelines, uniform totally clean. He looks near tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, if you haven't heard, it was announced during halftime that the N.F.L. Players Association will hold a press conference immediately following this game -- that would make it about five o'clock Eastern time -- and it is expected that the players' union will announce a strike effective immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ON REDSKINETTES
dialogues.text: Twelve striking-looking women dressed in burgundy and gold are doing some inane chatter to a section of fans that ignore them. The girls are led by pretty ANNABELLE FARRELL, a bundle of manic energy inside a body from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all about money, folks. More money, of course and ain't it always? The shame of it is the big losers are you out there, the fans.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARTEL
dialogues.text: The Redskin quarterback moves to the huddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go: Third down, eight seconds to play, ball on the Dolphins' thirty-three yard line. Skins down by a touchdown. The huddle breaks and Martel sets up over the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green 48! Green 48! Hut! Hut! The ball is snapped and Martel drops back. He looks for a receiver and doesn't see anybody. He steps up in the pocket, sees an opening and takes off running down field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes Martel! Martel is a pretty good broken field runner for a big guy. Plus with the defense covering every possible receiver, he's got a lot of daylight. Nobody has touched him as he crosses the fifteen. Suddenly, a safety, smaller than Martel, looms in front of him at the ten. Martel goes down in one of those wimpy quarterback slides before the safety can even hit him. BANG!   The GUN sounds and the game is over.

dialogues.speaker: ON MADDEN AND SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: They look at each other in disbelief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Martel goes down ten yards short of a score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On maybe the last play of the season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he might have slipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, there's a lot of that going around.

dialogues.speaker: ON THREE REDSKIN FANS
dialogues.text: We'll see these guys throughout. They're typical low level Washington bureaucrats named TODD, ROD and BOB who live for the Hogs -- the traditional name for the Redskin offensive linemen. Todd is shirtless and his entire upper body is painted Redskin red. At that moment, they are livid with their quarterback and Bob is speaking for them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're    coming to your house    tonight, and we're    gonna fucking kill    you! And if you got a    dog, we're gonna kill    your fucking dog too!

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Behind her, the rest of the cheerleaders are already walking away. Annabelle looks at Quarterback Martel with pure disgust as he walks off the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room's blinds are pulled tightly against the bright sunlight. Only the blue light of a TV illuminates anything. Suddenly, we hear an old man in the bed give out with a loud piercing wail. The door to the room bangs open and an English male nurse named AUGUSTINE RIPLEY, dressed in white, comes running in. He's carrying a syringe in each hand, poised at the ready. He runs to the bed of    the still wailing EDWARD FRANCIS O'NEIL    (75). O'Neil is hooked up to an oxygen tank,    watching the just completed Redskin game    with the sound off.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Did they win or lose?! O'Neil continues to wail.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: That has the distinct tonal quality of a loss. He puts one needle down and jabs O'Neil with the other one. He murmurs to the old man as he injects him.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Nice medicine for a loss. Keeps us calm. Makes us not so sad. Keeps us on an even keel. Gives us some perspective, doesn't it? And we'll save the winning medicine for next Sunday, won't we? He finishes.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: If you keep talking to me like I'm a five- year-old, I'm going to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Sounds exciting. He reaches for the phone and hits the speed dial.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: We'll want to talk to coach now, won't we? He hands the phone to O'Neil.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: (on the phone) What the fuck was that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Tildon sitting in his office. We can hear players getting dressed, listening to MUSIC and getting SHOWERS outside his open door.

dialogues.speaker: TILDON
dialogues.text: (on the phone) I think he slipped.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Bullshit he slipped! He could have scored! Anybody could have scored! I got one foot in the god damn grave and I could have scored!

dialogues.speaker: TILDON
dialogues.text: Mister O'Neil, let's face facts: The players are going out. It's gonna happen. And nobody wants to get hurt on the last play before a strike that could go on for the rest of the season.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: You god damn wimp! You're fired! Get out! Get out! Get out! O'Neil throws the phone down. Augustine picks it up and then cranks up the oxygen a notch. O'Neil takes big gulps of the rich air.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Better? It always makes you feel better when you fire someone, we know it does, don't we? Yes...

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Get me Jimmy McGinty. Get him here. Tonight. O'Neil sucks hard on the oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPORTER is interviewing WILSON JONES, the huge defensive end for the Redskins. Wilson wears an enormous diamond earring. Wilson is dressing at his locker.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I do what my union says.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: But you're already one of the highest paid players in the game. The fans just don't see the point of a player like you striking.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something: I'm a big man, you see? Wilson holds his arms out.   Yes, he's gigantic.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: There are some days when I am so beat up, that I cannot dress my own big ass. I asked management for a valet or some shit to help me dress and they said no way. So, fuck 'em!

dialogues.speaker: PLAYER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Shut up everybody, here it is... Somebody turns UP a TV in the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: A handsome ex-player named Jerome Lindell steps up to a podium at a press conference. He's wearing a two thousand dollar suit. On the TV he is identified with a super: "JEROME LINDELL -- President -- National Football League Players' Association."

dialogues.speaker: LINDELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have just left a meeting with representatives of the owners and I am sad to say that they have refused the players' final demands which center around a rise in the current salary cap. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, I am recommending that all N.F.L. players walk out and not play until our demands are met. I want the players to walk out tall, to walk out righteous, to walk out in the knowledge that we do this as a team. We shall overcome the fat cats. I send peace to my union brothers. The entire locker room is silent for a beat. And then everyone starts getting dressed again, maybe a little slower than before.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Shit, I'm goin' to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: As he sleeps peacefully.    The only sound is the HISS of his OXYGEN. Then we hear ICE CUBES SLOSHING in a glass. O'Neil opens his eyes and sees: JIMMY McGINTY, a handsome devil in his late sixties, wearing golf clothes and sipping the last dregs of a Scotch rocks. McGINTY You look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: I'm dying, Jimmy. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been dying for twenty years. O'Neil motions to the glass. Jimmy pours three fingers from a Glenlivet bottle and hands it to him. McGINTY That poof of a nurse of yours is gonna kick my ass if he catches you drinking. O'Neil removes his oxygen to sip his whiskey. He smiles as it goes down.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Gimme a butt. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I quit. O'NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. McGinty nods.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: You pussy. I want you to come back as head coach. I fired that asshole Tilden today. McGINTY I'm retired. And besides, you don't have a team. They all flew home in their jets to their castles.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: We're gonna finish the season anyway. All of us owners decided. We're gonna use replacement players. McGINTY You're a bunch of greedy bastards, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Us, greedy?! What about the god damn players?! I got the highest payroll in the N.F.L. and they still want more! McGINTY That's because you've been bottle-feeding straight cash to these big babies for years. O'Neil sips his whiskey and calms down.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: No team owner in their right mind is gonna give back those T.V. revenues. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All we promised Fox was twenty-two guys with a pulse every Sunday. But think about it, Jimmy. We got a great opportunity here! We got a chance to put a team on the field that plays the game just for the love of it. Like we used to play it. McGINTY We also used to play without face guards.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Jimmy, I'm really dying. The doctor says I'll be gone by Superbowl Sunday. Help me bring a winner back to D.C. You did it for me once before. You can do it again. McGINTY Listen: I golf once a week with the President of the United States. I walk my grandkids to school every day. I got a    young wife who will    fuck me any time I want,    which frankly, isn't    too often, but it's    comforting to know it's    there. I don't need    it.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Come on. Wouldn't it be fun? A bunch of poor nobodies who play to win instead of a bunch of bitchy millionaires? You can put it together, Jimmy. Player's love you. They always have. McGinty pours more Scotch and looks into the glass.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Tell me you're gonna do it. McGINTY Shut up, I'm thinking. (pause) Okay. Here's the deal: you let me recruit who I want, with no interference?

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Absolutely. McGINTY I'm talking anybody I want. No exceptions. And no interference with my coaching, either, like you used to.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Sure, Jimmy, sure. McGINTY And one more thing: no more Notre Dame stories. You start telling me Notre Dame stories and I pull your plug personally.   I swear to God. O'Neil smiles. O'NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGinty is sitting behind the empty desk as his two main coaches give him a presentation. They are offensive coordinator LEO PILACHOWSKI and defensive coordinator CHRISTOPHER BANES.

dialogues.speaker: PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: ... Six phone lines with internet access on two: One for defense and one for offense.

dialogues.speaker: BANES
dialogues.text: We thought we would skip special teams for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: Except for a kicker. We definitely need a kicker. A place kicker over a punter.

dialogues.speaker: BANES
dialogues.text: The thinking being that if we lose the toss, we have to be able to at least kick off. Both coaches laugh nervously.     McGinty doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: Okay. Here's the list of every player cut this past season. What we would like to do is... McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Those people? (pointing to list) Most of them were cut because they were shitty. McGinty takes out a piece of paper of his own with a bunch of names on it. McGINTY We're going to go another way here. I've done some scouting since I retired. On an ad hoc basis, of course. And what I have here is a list of people I've kept an eye on. They've all played football somewhere, but only a few in the pros. And they've all got something... unique to bring to the game. We're gonna take these people and try to put together a winning team. And if nothing else, they should be fun to watch. McGinty looks up when he senses someone standing in the doorway. It's REESE EVANS, the veteran Redskin we saw standing on the sidelines with the clean uniform.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: You won't need a center. McGINTY How you doin', Reese?

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Bored and ready to retire. I'm just looking for one more hit. One more really good hit. McGINTY What about the strike?

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Hell, I'm rich. I got no complaint with Mister O'Neil. I just want a chance to play one last time. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EVANS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit, I'd rather go out with a broken leg than sitting on the bench. McGinty nods to Pilachowski. The coach takes a marker and fills in "Evans" in the center circle. McGINTY Welcome to the new Washington Redskins. (to his coaches) Let's find Reese somebody to play with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of BIKER types are cooking up a vat of speed. These guys are big, and badasslooking. After a beat, one of the Bikers looks up at the door.

dialogues.speaker: BIKER
dialogues.text: Did you hear something? The other biker shakes his head, no. The one who asked the question walks over to the door and listens for a beat. Nothing. He turns to go back and suddenly the door disintegrates in front of a charging man wearing a "police" windbreaker. This is DANIEL    BATEMAN, a big,    young, psychotic cop,    who immediately    runs over the poor Biker who    was listening at    the door, kicking the guy    in the head as    he goes by. Bateman dives on two more Bikers, and viciously head-butts one of them. He stuffs the other's head into the meth mixture, pulls him out and clubs him with a big police blackjack, three quick times: Rap! Rap! Rap! The guy goes down like lead. Bateman looks around and spots a big BIKER cowering in a corner. The Biker is terrified. Bateman takes two stops toward the guy when suddenly three more COPS wearing windbreakers run in, out of breath. They look around at the unconscious Bikers.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Jesus, Bateman! Why don't you ever wait for us?! BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! Someone's BEEPER is going off. The three cops look at theirs. Nothing. The cowering Biker looks at his. BIKER #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. Bateman pulls his beeper, studies it and looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: BATEMAN
dialogues.text: What area code is 703?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Washington, D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loaf of Wonder Bread is spinning through the air in SLOW MOTION. It comes AT us, twisting and turning.

dialogues.speaker: ON CLIFFORD FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: He's tall, maybe 22, and positioned behind the cash register. He's wearing a Washington Redskins sweatshirt. Clifford's hands are up as he waits to catch the bread which was tossed by his MANAGER at the back of the store. The loaf hits Clifford's hands and then bounces out. It lands on the counter in front of a TEN-YEAR-OLD smart-ass KID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice hands.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: (not amused) What else?

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: A pack of Marlboro Reds, a pint of Martel Cognac and a box of Trojans, extra long. Clifford grabs the Kid's two one-dollar bills, and makes change for the bread.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Get out of here. I'm telling your mother you were talking like that. The Kid leaves. The Manager yells from the back of the store as he holds up a portable phone.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Hey, Clifford, somebody on the phone wants you to play football next weekend.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Tell 'em I gotta work Saturday. And I'm watching the Redskins on Sunday. Ain't nothing stopping me from watching the Redskins on Sunday. (mumbling) No way that's gonna be happening, me not watching the Redskins on Sunday. MANAGER (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gotta work. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said they'll pay you. CLIFFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay me?    How much? MANAGER (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten thousand five hundred dollars! CLIFFORD (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, who the fuck is on the phone?! MANAGER (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Washington Redskins! Clifford collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear deafening APPLAUSE as we hold on ANDRE and JAMAL WILLIAMS, two huge bodyguards, dressed in identical black suits. Suddenly,   the artist formerly known as Prince comes off   stage, grabs a towel from an assistant   and starts walking with Jamal in front and   Andre in the rear. As they walk, a CELL PHONE RINGS. Andre pulls it from his pocket and answers it, quietly. Jamal runs interference with the techies and groupies backstage.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: (to someone) Get out of the way! (to someone else) Don't look at him! He don't like being looked at, god damn it! No eye contact! As they walk, Andre is still talking on the phone. Finally, they get to the backstage door and stop. The rock star prepares to run the gauntlet of adoring fans behind his trusty bodyguards. But his bodyguards are conversing quietly but urgently with each other. One of the assistants throws open the door. A big mob waits outside. The anointed one turns to his bodyguards to lead the way, but... they're gone! The mob surges. The artist formerly known as Prince screams as he's trampled to death by his fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane Falco, wearing his patched wetsuit, climbs out of his inflatable dinghy and flops onto the deck of his cabin cruiser. He looks cold and tired. McGINTY (O.S.) You look like a swordfish I caught once. Shane jumps. McGinty is sitting in an old deck chair on the stern of the boat. McGINTY He hit the deck just like that. Shane studies his visitor.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: And you look like that coach from the Seventies. From the Redskins. McGinty. Except you look a shitload older. McGINTY The price of happiness. Something to take the chill off? He offers Shane an elegant flask.   Shane takes it and drinks. McGINTY I'm running the Redskins again. And I want you to quarterback 'em.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: No, man, I've been out way too long. McGINTY What, three years since San Diego dumped you? That's nothing. You're in shape, flopping around in the water like that.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: You know what my nickname was in San Diego, don't you? McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   Footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: As in, I hear 'em and I dump the ball. McGINTY Well, you didn't have much of a line to protect you.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: I got two concussions to prove it. McGINTY That's why girls don't play the game. McGinty drinks from his flask. McGINTY I scouted you when you were playing at Ohio State. I told San Diego they were probably making a mistake when they signed you.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: (truly shocked) No kidding? McGINTY Oh, you had a lot of tools: a quick release. Fast. A scrambler by nature. Good downfield vision. But you got hurt a lot. And worst of all, you never could win the big game. What did you lose the Sugar Bowl by, your senior year? What, forty points?

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Forty-five. And now you want to recruit me? McGINTY A scrambling quarterback is gonna do real well in this new replacement environment. And to tell you the truth, I think I can help you with your biggest problem. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   What's my biggest problem? McGINTY Courage. I think that Sugar Bowl took it all out of you. There's a beat as Shane looks away.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: I'm retired from football. McGINTY Yeah, and it looks like things have been going really well for you since. Shane doesn't meet McGinty's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: I like being here. It's quiet. I like being alone. McGINTY Yeah. No screaming crowds, that's for sure. (pause) You know what separates the winners from the losers? Gettin' back on the horse. The one that kicked you in the teeth. You're still young. You still got bags of talent. If you do well, who knows what will happen when the strike ends? Shane keeps staring out at the water. McGINTY You want me to tell you you're not going to get hurt? You know you will. No doubt about that. But, hell... McGinty points to the boats in the harbor. McGINTY ... Wouldn't you rather get hurt than scrape the shit off of other guys' toys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're right off Queens Boulevard on a busy side street where LOU PACIFICO, 30, is taking book. Lou is short, dark and handsome. He leans against the wall of a liquor store.

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: Deuce and an eightball on Go Down, Rita in the eighth. Lou writes quickly on a small pad. After a beat, another passerby leans in and whispers something to Lou. Lou writes quickly again. >From across the street an old woman sticks her head out of a four-story walk-up. This is LOU'S MOTHER who speaks with a heavy Italian accent.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Louis, you got a phone call!

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: (from across the street) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: It's the Washington Foreskins.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: What?! Ma, what are you, out a your tree?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (yelling louder) I'm telling you they said it's the Washington Foreskins! Foreskins! Foreskins! Foreskins! People in the street are now starting to look up at this old woman screaming "Foreskins!" Louis quickly crosses the street to his apartment house. But at that moment, a soccer ball bounces toward him from where a group of kids are playing in an alley. Out of pure instinct, Lou gives it a mighty boot. We FOLLOW the arc of the ball as it sails DOWN the block. Everyone stops to admire the kick. Still airborne, the ball crosses Queens Boulevard. At that moment, a very old mafioso type is being helped from his limo by several lieutenants. Pow! The ball hits the old guy right in the back of the head, knocking off his porkpie hat and dropping him to the pavement like a bullet. The lieutenants pull pistols and surround their fallen leader.

dialogues.speaker: ON LOU
dialogues.text: He sees what happens and quickly ducks into his apartment house.

dialogues.speaker: ON ONE MAFIA LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: He spots Lou before he disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach ROLAND LAMONT, a good-looking ex- running back in his late twenties, is coaching a high school player. We can see that Roland is wearing a pretty substantial knee brace. He holds up a football.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Cut right on me, now. Right on me. He pitches the ball out to one kid, who runs right at him, steps on Roland's foot with his cleats and then cuts around him. Roland screams and falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Not right on me, goddamn it! He writhes there a beat until he hears:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Coach Lamont! Phone call! Long distance. Washington, D.C. It's the Washington Redskins! Roland holds his foot and manages a smile because he seems to know what the phone call means.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (to the sky) Thank you, Lord!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stadium appears empty. Suddenly, a football thrown with a perfect spiral comes AT us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the ball sail cleanly through a rubber ring attached to the crossbar on the goalpost.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHANE FALCO
dialogues.text: He's in shorts and a sweatshirt taking snaps from center Reese Evans.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Nice. Try a roll to the right. Evans bends over another ball.    Shane sets up in the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shane 'Footsteps' Falco? This is what you're going to build an offense around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGinty is sitting with O'Neil on the fifty yard line twenty rows back. Augustine holds O'Neil's oxygen tank as the old man sits huddled in a coat that's way too big for him.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: Christ, Jimmy, I ask you to build me a team based on balls and the first player I see is Footsteps Falco?! McGINTY He's got as much natural talent as any quarterback in the league.

dialogues.speaker: O'NEIL
dialogues.text: And he's got the happiest feet I've ever seen! McGINTY All he needs is a shot of self-confidence. He's our quarterback. That's the way it is. O'NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about a safety? We got two a days starting tomorrow and a game in five days! And we still don't have a safety?! O'Neil motions to Augustine for more oxygen. AUGUSTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go. Nice fat little hits. He turns the valve up.   O'Neil breathes deeply. O'NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called a friend of mine who just happens to be the Governor of Maryland. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific, the Governor is going to play safety? O'NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHANE
dialogues.text: He drills a perfect spiral through the circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ramp at the rear of the stadium gives vehicle access to the interior. The bottom of this ramp is now a maelstrom of activity. The regular Washington Redskins are in a picket line walking in circles. The players are dressed in everything from fur coats to expensive leather jackets and leather pants. Half of them are on cell phones. We can see some of their cars parked haphazardly nearby: BMWs, Porsches, Mercedes, etc. Jerome Lindell, the president of the Players' Association, is being interviewed on camera by a REPORTER.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: As president of the Players' Association, what does your presence mean here, Mister Lindell?

dialogues.speaker: LINDELL
dialogues.text: Very simply, support for these fine players and union men. Washington D.C. is the home of freedom and the collective bargaining agreement. I am here to remind all Americans that the owners are no better than the robber barons of the Nineteenth Century. They have blatantly gone out and hired scabs, which is against all principles of our Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and probably even the Emancipation Proclamation. The picketers start shouting and pointing.

dialogues.speaker: LINDELL
dialogues.text: And here come the Scabskins now! A bus slowly makes its way towards the ramp and the picketers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane is sitting in the first seat with Reese Evans (center). We MOVE BEHIND them and see, among others, Daniel Bateman (psychotic cop), Clifford Franklin (can't catch a loaf of bread), Jamal and Andre Williams (ex-bodyguards), Lou Pacifico (kicker and bookmaker), and Roland Lamont (ex-high school coach). BANG! EGGS start HITTING the bus WINDOWS. We can hear the regular players chanting: PLAYERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scabskins! Scabskins! Scabskins!

dialogues.speaker: ON CLIFFORD FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: He's very excited as he looks out the window at the striking players. Roland Lamont sits next to him. CLIFFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, there's Eddie Martel! And Wilson Jones! I love Wilson Jones! Yo, Wilson! Yo, player!

dialogues.speaker: ON WILSON
dialogues.text: His big face looms right outside the bus window. He looks pissed off and scary.

dialogues.speaker: ON LOU PACIFICO
dialogues.text: He leans across his seat to Shane. LOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Lou Pacifico. Shane shakes his hand. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane Falco. LOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I lost a ton a money on that Sugar Bowl disaster of yours. Wow. Did you get your butt kicked or what?

dialogues.speaker: ON JAMAL
dialogues.text: He's looking out the window when an eeg splats against it. He turns to his brother Andre:

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: You know I don't take that shit. Jamal reaches into his jacket and starts to pull out a nine-millimeter pistol. Andre stops him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDRE
dialogues.text: Be cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nondescript van pulls up and a muscled, deadly-looking guy in handcuffs and jail issue clothes gets out. This is bearded safety EARL (he-ain't-no-girl) WILKINSON. A Maryland state trooper unlocks the cuffs. Earl looks... hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The replacements are getting off the bus as the players chant.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS
dialogues.text: Scabskins! Scabskins! When Reese Evans (former Redskin center) gets off the bus, the players go wild. Reese coolly gives them the international suck my dick sign. Clifford gets off behind him. He waves and smiles at the striking players. They throw rotten fruit at Clifford in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SID, an oldtimer equipment man folds towels. Behind him, we can see helmets, pads, etc. McGinty walks up dragging Shane who is fully dressed in a uniform, including helmet. McGINTY (to Sid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? McGinty points to the intricate face guard on Shane's helmet. It's an exaggerated version of a lineman's cage with so much metal criss-crossing that you can hardly see Shane's face. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a quarterback! How is he supposed to see? SID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me he was a linebacker! SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see. McGinty holds up three fingers. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many fingers? SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.   No, wait.    Three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andre and Jamal are hitting the blocking sled simultaneously. They drive it OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHANE
dialogues.text: He's now wearing a helmet with a twobar quarterback face guard. He takes a snap and pitches out to running back Roland Lamont. Roland, now wearing a big knee brace, looks sharp as he cuts to the outside.

dialogues.speaker: ON PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: The offensive coordinator is standing with McGinty who is concentrating on the scrimmage. Suddenly, Pilachowski spots someone. His mouth drops open.

dialogues.speaker: ON MICKEY LEE
dialogues.text: He's a fourhundred-fifty-pound ex-Sumo wrestler crammed into a Redskin uniform.     Fat rolls are visible everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: Oh my God. That's disgusting! Lee walks up. McGinty bows and says something in Japanese. Lee bows and answers back in Japanese. Then they shake hands. McGINTY How you doin', Mickey?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Not bad, Coach. McGINTY You look great. Why don't you work out at left tackle?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You got it. Lee puts on his helmet, pulls his ponytail out the back and rumbles away. Pilachowski is looking at McGinty like he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: You're not serious. McGINTY I met Mickey in Hawaii. When he was even bigger. He's a Sumo wrestler. That means he's an expert at pushing people around. That's what pass blocking is, Leo. Defensive coordinator Christopher Banes comes running up in a lather.

dialogues.speaker: BANES
dialogues.text: (to McGinty) I got a defensive end who's deaf!!

dialogues.speaker: PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: (watching Lee walk away) I'll trade you for a tackle who's gonna play in a diaper.

dialogues.speaker: BANES
dialogues.text: How can I coach a deaf man?! McGINTY You don't have to... He looks across the field at a big, good- looking kid named BRIAN MURRAY who is in the middle of a pass rushing drill. Murray looks really fast, especially for his size. McGINTY Brian Murray would have gone in the first round five years back if he hadn't been born deaf. I first saw him play right here in D.C. for Galludet College. He's a hell of an athlete. You won't have to tell him anything.

dialogues.speaker: BANES
dialogues.text: I can't believe it! I got to be able to communicate with him. McGINTY Then learn to sign. Hey, look at it this way: He'll never get pulled off sides on an audible. McGinty thinks this is funny as shit.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHANE
dialogues.text: He's just done a fivestop drop on a pass play. He's looking down field when he sees something scary. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! No! He throws the ball away and then is nailed and taken down on his back by Bateman (psychotic cop). Shane groans and lies there with Bateman on top of him. BATEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Danny. SHANE (groaning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane. McGinty pulls Bateman up. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice pop, Danny. BATEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank's, Coach! Danny runs off. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that? McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny Bateman. Ex-cop, ex-Marine, ex-rugby. He's absolutely harmless, if you just play dead. McGinty helps Shane up. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Diego used you all wrong. You're not a drop back passer. You're a scrambler. Like you were in college. So, we're gonna roll out. A lot. Get used to setting up on the run. You'll live a lot longer. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very interested in that.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: is lined up at middle linebacker. When the play starts, he runs headlong into four blockers and takes them all down with him.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: beats his man, and turns as Shane, rolling out to his left, puts the ball right on his numbers. Franklin drops it.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: On the snap, they pull to lead a sweep. Unfortu-nately, each thinks the play is to their side. They forearm each other and then get into a fight.

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: boots one from thirty-five yards through the uprights. He smiles, takes out a Marlboro Light and a Bic and fires up.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: pulls up, does a button hook and Shane puts the ball in his hands. Franklin drops it.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: the Sumo guy, hits the blocking sled and turns it over.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: is down on the ground viciously punching another player as two assistants try to pull him off.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: is in a crossing pattern in the end zone. Shane puts the ball right in front of him. Unfortunately, it hits him in the hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane is sucking down water from the portable water cart when head cheerleader Annabelle Farrell walks up. She's dressed in tight workout clothes. ANNABELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle Farrell, head Redskinette. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? ANNABELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in charge. Of the Redskinettes. The cheerleaders? SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, hi. ANNABELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been watching you. You look good. You look strong. Good quick release. Smart. You read defenses quickly. You're gonna do great. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... thanks. ANNABELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your second concussion. The one against Cleveland. Pow! You could hear it in the cheap seats. But you completed the pass. That's what counts.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: If there's anything you need, let me know. And I mean anything, okay? You understand? Shane is really not sure. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   I understand.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: They put you up at the Hilton? SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Good. Remember: anything. You got it? Okay? Shane nods.   She walks away. We watch her world-class ass move across the gridiron. ON McGINTY AND CLIFFORD FRANKLIN McGinty is holding a ball and talking to his wide receiver. McGINTY ... because it's a damn waste of all that speed, Clifford. I told you that when you were in high school. You've got to catch the ball, son. This is the main idea of the passing game.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: I know, Coach, I know. McGINTY Okay. I assume that you have touched a woman in a romantic way, have you not?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, Coach, sure. In a, you know, romantic way. McGINTY Good. From here on out, you touch this football, all the time... He shoves the football in Clifford's hands. McGINTY ... just like you touch your girl friends. I better not see you without this ball. You understand? McGinty starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Coach, wait! Can I still like touch my girl friends if I don't, you know, let go of the ball? McGinty thinks about that. McGINTY Yes, Clifford, if you can manage that, absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andre and Jamal are just about dressed. Andre helps Jamal on with his jacket.     Jamal then helps Andre on with his.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHANE
dialogues.text: He's stripped down sitting on a bench. Reporters are trying to interview him. Microphones are in his face and video cameras jockey for position. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... just glad to be back playing. That's all I've really got to say. REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where have you been? What have you been doing to make a living? SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I've been involved lately in the... aquatic business...

dialogues.speaker: ON MICKEY LEE AND ROLAND LAMONT
dialogues.text: Mickey is watching Roland unbuckle his big complicated knee brace. (NOTE: There should be something slightly medieval about this brace.) MICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only played one game?! ROLAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, less than two minutes. I was a rookie third round pick in '93. We were playing Atlanta in the home opener. Near the end of the first quarter, they sent me in, I took a screen pass over the middle and got hit by both linebackers. Simultaneously. One a side. My knee turned into wet toilet paper. End of career.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: Can you play on it now? Roland takes out a wrench and starts unscrewing a bolt on his brace.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I've been teaching high school football for five years. It's not a bad life. I'm good at it. There are some days when I actually love it. But for one more shot at this? Shit. I'd give it all up. This time, they're gonna have to take me out in a box.

dialogues.speaker: ON EARL WILKINSON, (CRIMINAL)
dialogues.text: He's standing naked in front of his locker staring with anticipation at a garment bag. Slowly, he unzips the bag revealing a beautiful new suit. He touches the lapels reverently.

dialogues.speaker: ON CLIFFORD FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: He's sitting in front of a locker, holding his football, with a shit-assed-eating grin. Someone walks by.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: I got Wilson Boone's locker, man. Do you believe that shit? He drops his ball and quickly picks it up again. He looks around to make sure Coach didn't see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regular Redskins are out in force, holding signs as they lean on their Beamers and Porsches. Shane pulls up in a battered '89 Honda. When he gets out, he's immediately surrounded by six striking regulars, led by quarterback Eddie Martel and defensive end Wilson Jones.

dialogues.speaker: MARTEL
dialogues.text: Hey, you can't park there.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Look, I don't want any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MARTEL
dialogues.text: You don't want any trouble?! You're taking my job away, but you don't want any trouble? (to Wilson) He doesn't want any trouble, but he puts this piece of shit in a no parking zone. Shane looks but it's obvious he's parked legally. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   I'll move it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTEL
dialogues.text: No, we'll do that for you. Go ahead, Wilson. Move it for him. Wilson motions to another big guy. The two of them proceed to roll the Honda over on its roof. It lands with a crunch.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You all put that car back. Everybody turns to see Andre and Jamal walking towards them.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDRE
dialogues.text: We're the people who take care of the quarterback. We're the guards. All the regulars laugh at this.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Put the car back. Gently.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Kiss my ass.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: (to Jamal) It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: No, it's not. Jamal points to a gorgeous midnight blue Porsche.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: (to Wilson) That's your ride, ain't it? Before Wilson can even answer, Jamal pulls his NINE MILLIMETER. BOOM! BOOM! No more Porsche windshield. All the regular Redskins dive for cover.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: My windshield! You crazy motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Move his car back. WILSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My car! Jamal raises his GUN again.    POW!   No Porsche driver's side window. WILSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!   Stop! He turns to his cowering teammates.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Come on, help me, god damn it! The guys quickly pick up the Honda and put it right side up.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (to Jamal) You are gonna pay for this.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: No I'm not. And quit messing with my man here. That includes his ride. Jamal spins the nine and holsters it. Andre and Jamal get on either side of Shane. They look at each other and then quickly switch sides.

dialogues.speaker: ANDRE
dialogues.text: Let's go to practice, Shane.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Let's do that. Shane smiles at his guards, smiles at the still-shocked Redskins, and they move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane, dressed in pads and pants, opens the door and walks in. During the opening and closing of the door we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so if anyone does have any firearms, we need to turn those in as soon as possible, no questions asked... Shane stands in front of the urinal and goes through the painstaking process of locating his dick. First he wrestles open his football pants and then has to deal with the cup, etc. Next to him, at another urinal, is WALTER COCHRAN, a big, serious bornagain tackle. As he pisses, Walter has his Bible propped open behind the flush handle so he won't miss a minute of scripture.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Praise the Lord, Shane. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Sure.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Walt Cochran. Offensive tackle. Shane nods.   Walter pees for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Shane, will you witness with me?

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Will I what?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Will you witness with me? For this upcoming practice. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? By now Shane is pissing too.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Praise the Lord for giving us a way to eliminate, Shane. Why not talk to Him in the midst of performing his gift? Walter takes his hand off his whizzing member and holds it out to Shane. Shane looks at Walter's hand for a long time, but finally, he removes his own guiding hand and clasps Walter's hand tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue pissing as they hold hands. WALTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavenly Father, thank you for allowing us to pee the poisons from our systems. Please help us in today's practice to be strong and...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. McGINTY'S HOUSE - DAY A barbecue is in progress for the new Washington Redskins at the beautiful home of Coach McGinty. The huge back yard features a pool and a catered buffet/barbecue. Andre and Jamal are loading down their plates. Mickey Lee is gnawing on a two-foot slab of ribs. Lou Pacifico has a little three card monty going at a picnic table. Coach    McGinty is holding up a beautiful baby girl    to the admiring players. He kisses the baby    and then hands the child to his gorgeous young    wife. Augustine is pushing Mister    O'Neil in a wheelchair. They pass the     outside bar and O'Neil suddenly lunges for    a bottle of tequila. Augustine has to     rip it out of his hands. Coach Banes and Earl Wilkinson (criminal) are talking to a distinguished-looking big man in his fifties. This is a D.C. CIRCUIT COURT JUDGE.

dialogues.speaker: BANES
dialogues.text: Where did you play, Judge? Wait. Do I call you judge?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Your Honor, or Judge is fine. I played at Harvard. But I played in the days when you went both ways. Offense and defense. When players were really tough. (to Wilkinson) And where did you play college ball... I'm sorry, what was your name again? Wilkinson is smiling but he looks dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINSON
dialogues.text: Smith. Ray Smith. I played at a junior college nobody ever heard of. What position did you play on defense, Judge?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Middle linebacker.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, big fellow like you, that's what I would have guessed.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: It was a different game in those days. Raw. Powerful. No tricks, like today.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINSON
dialogues.text: You know, maybe you can show me some of your technique, Your Honor. Maybe you can show me some of that toughness.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to! There's an evil glint in Wilkinson's eye. INT. McGINTY'S HOUSE - DAY Shane is standing alone in a large hallway looking at an enormous trophy case stuffed with the spoils of football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would think he's done enough. Shane turns and sees her.    She's as fetching as ever.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: McGinty, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: I was kind of thinking the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: My theory is he came out of retirement to see if he could win with losers. (pause) Oh, shit. I'm sorry. I didn't mean...

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Hey, it's okay. I've been called worse. ANNABELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like    after that Sugar Bowl    game? I guess you could    survive anything after    that. Shane has to actually smile at this.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I feel like everybody in the world saw that game. Like I could go to India and some little guy would run up to me and say, 'Boy, did you suck in the '92 Sugar Bowl.' Annabelle laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: So, how come you're such a fan?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: My dad. He's a huge Redskin fan. For years. He's in his twenty-ninth year at the Senate Office Building. As a guard, not a senator. The only thing that keeps him going he says, is me and the Redskins. That's where I get it. My fan-ness. (suddenly) Are you scared? Shane is totally taken off guard by this woman. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared? Well... yes. Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: It's okay. Anybody would be. But you're good. And you'll do good.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you. Look, I gotta study the play book tonight. So... I'll see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABELLE
dialogues.text: Break a leg tomorrow. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! ANNABELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's    from the theater. For    opening night. You say    the worst thing that    can happen. And it won't.   Break a leg. Shane waves uncertainly and walks away. EXT. McGINTY'S BACK YARD - DAY The Judge (now with his jacket off) and Wilkinson are lined up across from each other in a three-point stance in something called a man maker drill. The entire team forms two lanes on either side of them, as they face off. The idea is to knock the other guy down and get by him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Alright, this is how we used to stop a running back.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINSON
dialogues.text: I can't wait. Someone says hut! And Wilkinson slams into the Republican 16th Circuit Court Judge and knocks him head over heels. The Judge lands on his back, wham!   He's out cold. Wilkinson slaps hands with Andre and Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINSON
dialogues.text: Oooh... got me a judge! Man, that felt good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's another beautiful fall afternoon and cars are entering the stadium parking lot. At one of the entrances, the striking Redskins are picketing. Jerome Lindell (NFL Players President) is still marching with them. A little boy stops one of the Redskins and asks for an autograph on a program. The player gives it to him and the kid walks away. Lindell runs after the kid, grabs the program and rips off the page the player signed.

dialogues.speaker: LINDELL
dialogues.text: (to kid) Don't be asking    for no autographs from    the real players and    then go in and watch    the scabs! The kid retreats quickly.    Lindell rips up the page.

dialogues.speaker: LINDELL
dialogues.text: (to the player) That is not the message we want to send our children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very quiet. Shane sits in pads and no jersey, methodically squeezing a football. Reese Evans, his center, stops by.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: You okay? Shane nods and gives a nauseous-looking smile.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS
dialogues.text: Remember to nod your head on the snap.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: (out of it) Nod my head? EVANS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For    when Murray's in. The    deaf kid. Hello? He    needs to look at you on    the snap. Shane nods that he understands but he goes back to staring at a wall. Andre and Jamal sit facing each other. Andre throws a vicious forearm at Jamal's head but Jamal catches it. They both nod in approval. Lou Pacifico smokes and stares. Bateman is leaning against a wall, fully dressed, helmet on. He's staring into space and smiling to himself. He looks terrifying. Earl Wilkinson (the criminal) is polishing a beautiful pair of new alligator shoes. Clifford Franklin looks at himself in the mirror as he ceremoniously puts on his helmet. Walter Cochran is reading his Bible in front of his locker, which features a picture of Jesus and a cross. Mickey Lee (ex-sumo) is sitting in front of a bowl of hard boiled eggs. He's methodically popping them into his mouth. He eats four as we watch. Coach Pilachowski comes up to Lee and watches him eat.

dialogues.speaker: PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: What are you, crazy? Nobody eats right before a game.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I always ate before a big match. I need the bulk. Like a hole in the head he needs the bulk. Coach McGinty comes strolling through the locker room, the picture of calm. He walks by defensive end/tight end Brian Murray and signs to him to have a good game. Murray signs back, "Thanks, Coach." Cochran spots McGinty and puts down his Bible.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: Coach McGinty, I'd like to lead the team in the pregame prayer. McGINTY No. No praying. That's the problem with professional sports today: too much god damn praying. Five hundred dollar fine to the first man I hear praying. McGinty turns and bums an egg from Mickey and walks to the middle of the locker room. He eats the egg as he turns slowly and takes in his players. McGINTY A lot of people are waiting for you to fall on your asses today. And guess what? You're going to. But I don't give a shit if you look funny out there. Or if you miss a block, or drop a pass, or trip over your own dick. This is professional. And the difference between professional and amateur, between playing for the Washington Redskins and Michigan State is simply... money. You are being paid to win. Not just to play. Not just to learn how to be good sports. Not for the alumni. You are being paid to win. I don't care how the fuck you do it. But I'm demanding it. Because those guys whose place you're taking have forgotten that simple fact. So, go win it. He walks away.   The players get up and start moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're FOCUSED ON an enormous,    plastic blow-up Washington Redskin helmet that    bobs on the ground in front of the exit to    the field. The idea is, the players will    run into and then out of the helmet as they    are introduced. Annabelle and her fellow twenty cheerleaders are lined up on either side of the bobbing helmet, waiting for the players.

dialogues.speaker: ON MADDEN AND SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: They are in their booth, vamping ON CAMERA. MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Pretty bold move by New England Patriot owner Victor Kiam, who went out and bought an entire semi-pro team once the strike happened. (MORE) MADDEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redskin management, on the other hand, is going with a bunch of unknowns. Their public relations people don't even have bios yet on most of their players, although we'll see one or two familiar faces out there today. SUMMERALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Shane Falco, the enormously talented college quarterback from Ohio State, who never fulfilled his potential in the pro's. (to Madden) Wow, remember that Sugar Bowl Falco quarterbacked when Florida State creamed them? MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, they were absolutely decimated! SUMMERALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusted. And if I'm not mistaken, Falco set a record in that game for Bowl interceptions. Anyway, for some of these players this is another shot; a last shot, probably, for a guy like Falco...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane is looking out at the field through the blow-up helmet. He looks scared. Suddenly, a CANNON goes off with a stomach- resounding BOOM! Shane jumps. ANNOUNCER (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, your Washington Redskins!

dialogues.speaker: IN STANDS
dialogues.text: A sparse crowd is in attendance, mostly diehard fans like Todd, Rod and Bob, who are decked out in burgundy and gold. They look drunk already as they cheer like mad. ANNOUNCER (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the starting defense today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bateman is first in line.    He looks like a racehorse on cocaine. ANNOUNCER (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At middle linebacker, number 56, Daniel Bateman! Bateman takes off at a dead run out of the tunnel and into the helmet.

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS FOOT
dialogues.text: It hits a wire stretched across the ground inside the helmet.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATEMAN
dialogues.text: He trips big-time into the side of the helmet. He bounces (it's inflated, remember?) to the other side, bounces again and is shot out of the front of it like a cannon ball.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHEERLEADERS
dialogues.text: Bateman bounces out of the helmet and takes out the first six cheerleaders. Girls fly left and right.       One girl is knocked out of her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ON MADDEN AND SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: Madden covers his face.     Summerall looks pained. SUMMERALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my...

dialogues.speaker: IN STANDS
dialogues.text: Even the hardcore Todd, Rob and Bob can hardly look at the carnage.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE STANDS
dialogues.text: A contingent of strike players like Eddie Martel and Wilson Jones huddle in the parking lot. They are laughing their asses off as they watch on a personal TV.

dialogues.speaker: ON FIELD
dialogues.text: Cheerleaders are down and screaming in pain. Annabelle is running from girl to girl, doing triage.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATEMAN
dialogues.text: He's sheepishly standing to one side as trainers come out to assist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal and Shane are examining the trip wire. Obviously, they were sabotaged. JAMAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastards. ANNOUNCER (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now... uh, the rest of the Washington Redskins. The rest of the team walks unceremoniously out of the helmet and onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM! The Patriot kicker puts one in the end zone for a touchback. The ball is placed on the twenty as Shane and the offense walk out onto the field. Shane walks slowly toward the huddle that's forming.

dialogues.speaker: IN HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Andre and Mickey Lee are arguing. ANDRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I stand. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not. ANDRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man, that's my spot in the huddle.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHANE
dialogues.text: As he walks, we hear McGinty's voice in Shane's helmet. Yes, they do it by one-way helmet radio so the filtered voice you hear is McGinty, speaking into his headset mike. McGINTY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, son, nice and easy now. Let's run our ten planned plays, get a feel for the land... Shane walks into the huddle and chaos. ANDRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Fat fucking nip! You don't know shit! LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you call me?! ANDRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me, you tub a rice shit! SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, what's the problem here? Andre and Lee ignore Shane and start pushing each other. LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna kick your black ass... ANDRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't kickin' jack shit... Now Jamal gets involved as Shane tries to get between them. JAMAL (to Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be messing with my brother... SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hold on...

dialogues.speaker: ON REF
dialogues.text: He's watching the play clock and when it gets to zero he pulls his penalty flag and throws it. REF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delay of game!    Five yards!

dialogues.speaker: IN HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Lee suddenly punches Andre through his face guard. Andre knocks into Shane and spins him around. Jamal then goes to punch Lee, he misses and nails Shane in the back of the helmet. Shane goes down hard.

dialogues.speaker: ON MADDEN AND SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: They look confused. SUMMERALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I don't know. Something seems to be going on in the huddle. It looks like... yes, Shane Falco is on his back. They haven't run a play yet but Falco is down. MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a good sign.

dialogues.speaker: ON FIELD
dialogues.text: Trainers race out to Shane, who is lying face up with the huddle standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: (clearing the cobwebs) What happened? Am I hurt already? Shane sits up.   Suddenly, he remembers what happened.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: God damn it! I am the quarterback! I am the only one supposed to talk in the huddle!

dialogues.speaker: ANDRE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he took my place...

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit! Shane gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Huddle up! Everybody leans in.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: If you've got something to say, raise your hand! Is that understood?! Lee raises his hand.   Shane grits his teeth and nods.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Suppose like, you don't feel good. Or you're hurt or something like that. Then what?

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Then you tell me before the huddle starts! Okay, listen up: 68 blue east storm toss. On two. Jamal raises his hand. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! JAMAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's to the right... right? ANDRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's to the left. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's to the right! JAMAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better be quiet, Shane, they'll hear you. We do hear a WHISTLE.        A penalty flag flies by. REF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delay of game!     Five yards! Shane throws ups his hands. ON McGINTY He's talking into his mike. McGINTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: ON MADDEN AND SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Pat, so far the Redskins have minus ten yards offensively.

dialogues.speaker: ON O'NEIL
dialogues.text: He's in bed sucking oxygen watching the game. Augustine sits with him. O'NEIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it off. This is going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: ON REDSKIN HUDDLE
dialogues.text: It breaks this time and everyone runs to the line of scrimmage. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue 68. Blue 68! Hut! Hut! On the snap, Shane turns to head off to Lamont but instead runs right into Jamal who knocks him down. Shane looks up at Jamal. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you suddenly decided you don't like me, Jamal? JAMAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. You said it was to the right, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: IN HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Shane leans in. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's try something simple. 18 red left slot open. (to Jamal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's to the left! They break and Shane lines up over his center. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen red! Eighteen red! Hut! Hut! On the snap, Shane hands to Lamont who sweeps left, cuts inside and picks up eight yards. Shane is ecstatic. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! And then a penalty flag flies by.

dialogues.speaker: REF
dialogues.text: Holding! Number 78. Shane looks at Jamal who is trying desperately to hide his number. Shane leans in with the next play. Cochran, playing right tackle, can't resist.

dialogues.speaker: COCHRAN
dialogues.text: You see. We should have prayed.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Shut up! Pass. 22 Solo right slot 'A,' Y stick. On one. They break and come to the line of scrimmage.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Twenty-two green.    Hut! Shane does a play action fake to Lamont and then turns downfield. Wham! He's buried by three defenders. The ball squirts loose and the Patriots recover.

dialogues.speaker: ON PILACHOWSKI
dialogues.text: He's livid on the sidelines. As his offensive line comes off he rants at them. Shane hobbles off past: The defense rushing onto the field led by Bateman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington comes up a minus fourteen yards on their first possession.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATRIOTS
dialogues.text: They break their huddle and come to the line of scrimmage. Bateman is snorting fire. Earl Wilkinson (with SMITH on the back of his jersey) patrols the secondary and calls out the formation. EARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide right! You got wide right! Check on the wing! The PATRIOT QUARTERBACK sets up over center. PATRIOT QB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue fourteen! Bam! Bateman runs offside and flattens the quarterback. Penalty flags fly everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ON SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Defensive Coordinator Banes rolls his eyes. The Ref moves the ball five yards and gives the offside sign.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATRIOTS
dialogues.text: They come out of the huddle again. PATRIOT QB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green eighty-seven! Pow! Bateman dives offside again and forearms the Quarterback, knocking him on his back. Flags fly again. One Patriot lineman makes the mistake of pushing Bateman. Bateman literally jumps on his head. More flags fly.

dialogues.speaker: ON SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Banes is screaming something unintelligible at Bateman.

dialogues.speaker: ON BALL
dialogues.text: It's marched downfield by the Ref, this time fifteen yards. OVER this we hear: SUMMERALL (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the Redskins just set a record for penalties in the first three minutes. We're waiting for the stats on that... Here come the Patriots again.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: rolls to his right but the blitz    is on and he reverses and rolls left.     He's finally cornered and has to dump    the ball off. The pass is incomplete and     he's knocked on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: fakes to Lamont and rolls again.     He fires a bullet to Franklin on a    down and out. Clifford actually catches     the ball, then bobbles it and in trying to    get possession again, hands the ball    to the defender. The defender can't believe it for a beat and then he streaks down the sideline and scores. C)    McGINTY just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: scream in pain. Rod pours his own beer over his own head.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: looks disgusted as he watches with Augustine.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: grabs the opposing running backs' face mask and spins him around and around. Flags fly everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: is on the run again looking for a receiver. He finally throws the ball... right into the hands of the opposing safety. Shane dives for the guy and misses.   The safety scores.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: is trying desperately to get the crowd into the game by jumping up and down and waving her pom poms. Five guys right in front of her get up from their seats, take all their stuff and leave.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: shows the Patriots up 17 to 0.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHANE
dialogues.text: He's rolling in the back field again looking for a receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but meat coming at him.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Shane panics and tosses the ball out of bounds. Shane looks at McGinty on the sidelines. We hear McGinty's voice. McGINTY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had Lamont open in the flat. Shane puts his head down like he knows it. McGINTY (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, now, son. Pick up your pace on the roll. See the big picture. Pump and fake, pump and fake.

dialogues.speaker: IN HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Everyone is dirty, sweating bullets and breathing very hard. Shane leans into the huddle. Lee is raising his hand. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel good. And with that he promptly vomits sixteen eggs. ANDRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God! COCHRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooooh... JAMAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, that's ripe! Everyone is reacting.       Some players gag. EVANS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shane, we got to move! SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. On the count of three. Everyone more left. Hut! Hut! Hut!

dialogues.speaker: ON HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Eleven bentover guys move in unison with tiny steps to their left.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATRIOTS' LINEBACKER
dialogues.text: The guy watches the huddle moving. PATRIOT LB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: ON MADDEN AND SUMMERALL
dialogues.text: Summerall has his binoculars on the moving huddle. SUMMERALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, how many years have we been calling games together? MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen, I think. Pat just hands John the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: IN HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Shane calls the play as they continue to move as one. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U brown right, west 19 A lead. That's you, Mickey. Puke on him if you have to.

dialogues.speaker: ON HUDDLE
dialogues.text: The huddle stops and they break for the line of scrimmage.

dialogues.speaker: ON LEE
dialogues.text: He lines up face to face with the Patriots' defensive end. Lee breathes in the guy's face and the Patriot gags. SHANE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hut! Lee runs right over the guy.       He's quickly followed by Lamont with the ball. Lamont runs for eighteen yards and a first down.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATRIOT DEFENSIVE END
dialogues.text: He's waving for a substitute as he weaves off the field.

dialogues.speaker: MADDEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Very nice off tackle run by Lamont. Execution was letter perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That puts the Redskins in field goal range. And here comes Pacifico to see if he can get them on the board before the half ends.

dialogues.speaker: ON PACIFICO
dialogues.text: He flicks his smoke away as he runs out onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy sitting at the bar turns his head quickly to the televised game when he hears Pacifico's name. This is the same mafioso type who saw Lou kick the ball that knocked the godfather's hat off. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crouches down and waits for the snap from Evans. Pacifico lines himself up.

dialogues.speaker: MADDEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This will be a forty- five yarder. That's a tough distance for your first N.F.L. field goal try. SHANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hut! It's a perfect snap.   Shane spots it, Pacifico belts it. And it goes through for three.

dialogues.speaker: ON TODD, ROD AND BOB
dialogues.text: They begin immediately singing "Hail to the Redskins," a march always sung after a score. They and the sparse crowd in the stadium know and sing every word.

dialogues.speaker: ON PACIFICO
dialogues.text: He gets high fives all around. Then Bateman runs up and in his ecstasy, slaps Pacifico in the head. Pacifico goes down, knocked out cold.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHEERLEADERS
dialogues.text: Led by Annabelle, the girls are doing a stirring finale to "Hail to the Redskins."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is lying on the floor. Shane has ice bags on his head, shoulder, elbow and both knees. Pacifico is getting smelling salts from a trainer as Bateman hovers nearby waiting to apologize. Mickey Lee is chewing ice. Cochran is reading his Bible. McGinty walks in and bends down to Shane. McGINTY (quietly) You got to look for Murray over the middle. You got to trust me on this: he's a big, tough kid with good hands.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: We can't put three plays together without a penalty, a fumble of a fight. McGINTY You still got a whole half left. You're a thoroughbred out there running against a bunch a nags. You can pick these fuckers apart. Shane smiles through his pain.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: You're good. You're really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Patriots have the ball. Their Quarterback drops back for a pass and throws it.

dialogues.speaker: ON WILKINSON
dialogues.text: Earl is covering the intended receiver. He deftly steps in front of the guy, and makes a diving catch.

dialogues.speaker: SUMMERALL
